construction, Lp spaces
  1. Let 1≤p<∞1 \leq p < \infty1≤p<∞. Show that if a sequence of real-valued functions {fn}n≥1\set{f_n}_{n\geq1}{fn​}n≥1​ converges in Lp(R)L^p\p{\R}Lp(R), then it contains a subsequence that converges almost everywhere.
  2. Give an example of a sequence of functions converging to zero in L2(R)L^2\p{\R}L2(R) that does not converge almost everywhere.
Solution.

  1. By definition, there exists f∈Lp(R)f \in L^p\p{\R}f∈Lp(R) such that ∥fn−f∥Lp→0\norm{f_n - f}_{L^p} \to 0∥fn​−f∥Lp​→0. Thus, there exists n1n_1n1​ so that ∥fn1−f∥Lp≤2−1/p\norm{f_{n_1} - f}_{L^p} \leq 2^{-1/p}∥fn1​​−f∥Lp​≤2−1/p. By induction, there exists a subsequence {nk}k≥1\set{n_k}_{k\geq1}{nk​}k≥1​ such that ∥fnk−f∥Lp≤2−k/p\norm{f_{n_k} - f}_{L^p} \leq 2^{-k/p}∥fnk​​−f∥Lp​≤2−k/p. Now consider

    FN=∑k=1N∣fnk+1−fnk∣pandF=∑k=1∞∣fnk+1−fnk∣p.F_N = \sum_{k=1}^N \abs{f_{n_{k+1}} - f_{n_k}}^p \quad\text{and}\quad F = \sum_{k=1}^\infty \abs{f_{n_{k+1}} - f_{n_k}}^p.FN​=k=1∑N​∣fnk+1​​−fnk​​∣pandF=k=1∑∞​∣fnk+1​​−fnk​​∣p.

    Since the terms are non-negative, {FN}N≥1\set{F_N}_{N\geq1}{FN​}N≥1​ is an increasing sequence of functions, so by the monotone convergence theorem,

    ∥F∥L1=∑k=1∞∥fnk−f∥Lpp≤∑k=1∞2−k=1.\norm{F}_{L^1} = \sum_{k=1}^\infty \norm{f_{n_k} - f}_{L^p}^p \leq \sum_{k=1}^\infty 2^{-k} = 1.∥F∥L1​=k=1∑∞​∥fnk​​−f∥Lpp​≤k=1∑∞​2−k=1.

    Thus, ∣F∣<∞\abs{F} < \infty∣F∣<∞ almost everywhere, so by the divergence test for series, it follows that ∣fnk−f∣→0\abs{f_{n_k} - f} \to 0∣fnk​​−f∣→0 for almost every x∈Rx \in \Rx∈R, i.e., {fnk}k≥1\set{f_{n_k}}_{k\geq1}{fnk​​}k≥1​ converges to fff almost everywhere.

  2. Consider the typewriter sequence: for n≥1n \geq 1n≥1 and 1≤k≤2n−11 \leq k \leq 2^{n-1}1≤k≤2n−1, set

    In,k=[k−12n−1,k2n−1]andfn,k=χIn,k.I_{n,k} = \br{\frac{k - 1}{2^{n-1}}, \frac{k}{2^{n-1}}} \quad\text{and}\quad f_{n,k} = \chi_{I_{n,k}}.In,k​=[2n−1k−1​,2n−1k​]andfn,k​=χIn,k​​.

    For each n≥1n \geq 1n≥1, {In,k}k\set{I_{n,k}}_k{In,k​}k​ partition the interval [0,1]\br{0, 1}[0,1]. Thus, for any xxx and n≥1n \geq 1n≥1, there exists kkk so that fn,k(x)=1f_{n,k}\p{x} = 1fn,k​(x)=1, but fn,k−1(x)=0f_{n,k-1}\p{x} = 0fn,k−1​(x)=0 if k>1k > 1k>1 or fn,k+1(x)=0f_{n,k+1}\p{x} = 0fn,k+1​(x)=0 if k=1k = 1k=1, so fn,kf_{n,k}fn,k​ converges nowhere pointwise. On the other hand,

    ∥fn,k∥L22=12n−1→n→∞0,\norm{f_{n,k}}_{L^2}^2 = \frac{1}{2^{n-1}} \xrightarrow{n\to\infty} 0,∥fn,k​∥L22​=2n−11​n→∞​0,

    so fn,k→0f_{n,k} \to 0fn,k​→0 in L2(R)L^2\p{\R}L2(R).
